title: Erdős Problem #151: Clique Transversal and Triangle-Free Independence
description: Is τ(G) ≤ n − H(n) for every n-vertex graph G, where τ is the clique transversal number and H(n) is the triangle-free independence number?

overview.historicalContext: Erdős and Gallai conjectured that the clique transversal number τ(G) is at most n − H(n), where H(n) is the largest independent set guaranteed in triangle-free n-vertex graphs. The easy bound τ ≤ n − √n follows from Ramsey theory. Even the K₄-free case is open. Erdős described the conjecture as 'perhaps completely wrongheaded.'
overview.problemStatement: Is τ(G) ≤ n − H(n) for every graph G on n vertices?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization axiomatises cliques, maximal cliques, independence, and triangle-freeness. Defines clique transversals and axiomatises τ(G) and H(n) with their specifications. The easy bound and the main conjecture are stated.
keyInsights: τ(G) is the minimum vertex set hitting every maximal clique of size ≥ 2
H(n) ~ √n by Ramsey theory (R(3,k) gives triangle-free independent sets)
The easy bound τ ≤ n − √n falls short of the conjecture
Even the K₄-free case remains open

sections.title: Main Conjecture
sections.summary: Erdős–Gallai: τ(G) ≤ n − H(n) for all n-vertex graphs.

conclusion.summary: The formalization captures the Erdős–Gallai conjecture (Problem 151) relating clique transversal numbers to triangle-free independence numbers.
conclusion.implications: A proof would connect two fundamental graph invariants: the clique transversal number and the Ramsey-theoretic function H(n), giving a universal upper bound on τ.
openQuestions: Is τ(G) ≤ n − H(n) for all graphs?
Does the conjecture hold for K₄-free graphs?
Is the conjecture 'completely wrongheaded' as Erdős suggested?
